ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Would have liked one class period early in the semester dedicated to talking about how authors choose the outline for a full story. We read many pieces and examples but didn't sit back and think about the roadmaps these authors use enough. This exercise would have been very helpful when, mid-semester, we were asked to start full drafts of our work and all I had was a handful of scenes and no sense of what I was trying to say. I found myself doing this exercise later in the semester than I would have liked.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: You learn from the experience of the instructor, the insights of your classmates, and your own process as you work through a full length article over the semester.

Fred is an incredible teacher of writing; and he is incredibly engaged with students and their work. He edits work in detail EVERY week, providing structured feedback and areas for improvement. He's also incredibly positive, quick to complement and to solicit complements from others. Working with Fred is an honor, and the highlight of this course. Additionally, each student in this class is working on one long-form piece of journalism that is unique to their experiences/interests; so I learned a huge amount from reading and editing my peers' pieces.
The course is a writing course. The foci are writing, reading good writing, discussing good writing. All excellent.

Great example readings, cool to dive into what makes a sentence great, how to create your audience, etc. Very good for the lit nerds among us. Fast paced could be good and bad. Loved having workshops at the end, wish we had met more often. Or maybe full workshop one week, partner workshop the next, etc.
Convivial learning environments - Fred does not let you off the hook until you have fully developed an argument. A great mind!
The input from fellow students! When we were workshopping each others texts. Fred's individual detailed input on all of our work The readings were very fun, and so was the in-class discussion

This course is an incredible opportunity to explore writing a piece of environmental journalism if you already have had the experience (that your planning on writing about) and have conducted the research. FS is an excellent and attentive editor, who will give you ample time and feedback. I was amazed at his diligence. It was a pleasure to be able to work with him over the course of the semester, particularly one-on-one or in the larger classroom setting while workshopping our pieces.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Nothing needs to be improved, in my opinion.

the in-class portion often felt crazed/rushed and some students felt that Fred could talk down to them/dismissively. I think it's his style to rush us towards the answer he wants but he often didn't notice when a student felt put down by a comment. See section above above in Q13 about having a class devoted to roadmapping your story. Please please please give us a 10-15minute break in the middle of the 3hour long class. We need it desperately.

Better wrap-up of discussions - e.g. the take-away messages from the analysis of the texts. More in-depth theoretical explanations. Maybe using Word control changes function for editing and commenting on the drafts, which has its limitations but is not as messy as using the variety of fonts, bold, italicized styles that Fred uses, and make it look really cluttered. Stating from the beginning how to keep track of sources. Cover methods for being organized in keeping track of sources, how to take field notes, photos, quotes, etc. - tips for when we are out in the field soaking everything in to write a piece.

I thought that the discussion sections of this course when discussing readings were the portion of the course that needed the most improvement. Often reading discussions would cramp the time available to actually discuss our pieces particularly early in the semester. Discussions often felt forced. While I appreciated that FS was trying to get lead us a particular direction, I often felt stifled by this, as I may have something that I wanted to say but didn't know what exactly FS wanted me to say. This is particularly pertinent, as we do not discuss matters that have right and wrong answers. While I greatly appreciated many portions of the course, I often felt frustrated during the reading discussions. The readings are great, but also would have appreciated if the instructor had just chosen which readings we were going to be discussing. To get through readings I was often glossing over some incredible pieces or would just select the pieces that were of interest to me. Would have been great to actually know which pieces we were going to discuss so that I could have focused my reading and then used my remaining time to explore the supplemental readings. Also, assessment was completely unclear as we did not actually receive a grade on any portion of work all semester. I would have appreciated a more clear outline of how grading would be conducted.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Perfect. We discussed what we and others wrote. We discussed good writing.
We had a "lab" section in class, the workshops, and these were great.
see prior comments

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course teaches a totally different sort of writing than you do in the rest of your academic career. I found it to be both cathartic and extremely intellectually challenging, in a very good way. I think it's important to know how to write like this, and to know what to look for in other people's writing -- how to evaluate their pieces.
I am doing environmentally focused work
This is an amazing opportunity (and one of the few at FES) to actually explore an environmental topic from a journalistic perspective. I would recommend for anyone that was interested in this.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to write about a topic which I'm hoping to develop expertise around in as many different ways as possible. Also, writing is good for the soul.
I want to write better. I want to know how to write well about environment.
FES needs more "skills"-based classes and this was a great one to take.
Desire to improve writing/story-telling skills
Wanted to improve my non-technical writing to better communicate my work and that of others to a wider audience. Love reading Sage magazine, Nat Geo, etc. so wanted to write a great piece!
I am interested in environmental journalism.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Definitely. So much so that I might take this class again.
Yes. Very well.
Great reminder/introduction to skills I wish I had focused on more while I was a FES. Very glad I took this class.
yes
Yes,mostly.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We were split into revising teams in the latter half of the semester. My team provided GREAT feedback, and I hope I met their expectations as well. It was satisfying to watch our pieces evolve together.
I took the 1-credit version of the course, so I did not participate in a small work groupt.

Workshopping papers with fellow students was amazing: great feedback and a chance to engage with peers at FES in a way you often miss in other classes. I loved hearing what other people were passionate about and helping them create a piece that furthered their goals.
I thought that the smaller working groups were great! Really appreciated the feedback.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take this course if you want to be a better writer.
Have a really clear project to write about. Don't try to complete a project during the course while you're writing.
If you want to write better, take the course! The 1-credit choice makes the course more possible for more students.
Fred can be kind of intense but if you have a piece you want to write and need some help/motivation getting it done, take this class. Also take this class if you just want to work on your writing!
I liked it. If you have a good subject to write about, the course is a good motivation to actually produce a great piece.
